thread.title: Lady Indians sweep Lakeside-DeKalb, will face Collins Hill
thread.title_full: Lady Indians sweep Lakeside-DeKalb, will face Collins Hill

title: Lady Indians sweep Lakeside-DeKalb, will face Collins Hill
text:
Comments 
East Coweta’s Kelley Lynch prepares to connect with an RBI triple during Wednesday’s sweep. 
East Coweta softball coach Franklin DeLoach knows the road to a state championship is going to get a whole lot harder than what Wednesday’s first-round series chalked up to be. 
Still, the Lady Indians did exactly what needed by sweeping outmatched Lakeside-Dekalb 8-0 and 15-1 in games called that ended early by the mercy rule. 
The victory sets up a best-of-three second-round contest Wednesday at home against Region 7- runner-up Collins Hill (20-10), which swept North Forsyth on Wednesday. 
Collins Hill, last year’s 7- champion, reached last year’s Sweet 16 before losing to Pope. 
“It’s a tough bracket. Somebody who should be in Columbus is going to be sitting at home,” DeLoach said. “The second-round bracket is tough this year.” 
Despite the lack of competition against the Lady Vikings, DeLoach used the opportunity to play his entire roster. 
All three pitchers went to the circle with Rachel Vaughan throwing a perfect game in the opener. The sophomore southpaw, who plays first when not in the pitching circle, struck out six, walked one, and had just one pitch leave the infield. 
Senior Morgan Goree, who started game two, allowed her first batter to reach base, but was unhittable from there, striking out eight of the nine recorded outs through three innings. 
The Lady Vikings scored their only run in the doubleheader in the top of the fourth, but relief pitcher Kelley Lynch struck out the side to end the contest by the mercy rule. 
East Coweta outhit the Lakeside DeKalb 23-1 and the Lady Vikings committed 15 errors over the two games. 
East Coweta took control of game one with two runs in the first, three in the third, two in the fourth and one in the fifth. 
The Lady Indians picked plenty of support from the top of the order in the first game with seniors Mekhia Freeman and Madison Carter each driving in a run. Carter finished the contest with a 3-for-3 performance. 
In addition to a strong pitching performance Vaughan also drove in a run. Ashlynn Gunter and Lindsey Warren also had an RBI in the first game, with Vaughan, Gunter and Warren each posting doubles. 
Freeman and A.J. Estrada each with triples. 
East Coweta put the second game away early, scoring 10 run in the first two innings. 
In addition to her pitching performance, Lynch led second contest by going 3-for-4 at the plate with three RBIs, two of which came on a two-run homer in the top of the fourth. 
Freeman added to her offensive totals in the second game with an RBI. 
Vaughan, Sheynne Bell, Gunter, Warren, Jessica Barber and Jamie Vitale also drove in runs in game two. 
“The good thing about a game like this is we were able to get a lot of different players into the lineup,” Deloach said. “We wanted to use all three of our pitchers and we did.” More
